title-group.article-title: Mechanical Impedance Approach to Engine Vibration Transmission Into an Aircraft Fuselage

abstract.p: The paper demonstrates a mechanical impedance approach to an aircraft vibration problem. The desire is to reduce cabin noise resulting from fuselage vibration generated by engine rotor unbalance disturbances. A simplified analytical model is used in combination with experimental impedance data to investigate the effectiveness of several schemes applied to the engine/airframe interface. Airframe vibration absorbers are found to be the most effective. Qualitative correlation is achieved with the results of the installation of absorbers on the Douglas DC-9 aircraft. A more comprehensive analytical model is generated to account for three-dimensional effects; data acquistion for this model is discussed.

p.mixed-citation: These approaches were suggested by R. Thorn of the Lord Manufacturing Co., Erie, Pa. and are considered in Lord Engineering Report No. 03418-3 "Engineering Study of En- gine Vibration Isolators for the Douglas DC-9 Aircraft," March 1966.

ref.mixed-citation: J. D. Van Dyke, Jr., J. W. Schendel, C. O. Gunderson, M. R. Ballard, "Cabin Noise Reduction in the DC-9." Paper 67-401, presented at the ALAA Commercial Aircraft Design Meeting, June 1967 (also Douglas Paper 4303).
C. T. Molloy, "Four Pole Parameters in Vibration Analysis." Colloquium on Mechanical Impedance Methods for Mechanical Vibration, Transactions ASME, Vol. 80, De- cember 1958, pp. 43-68.
S. Rubin, "Review of Mechanical Immittance and Transmission Concepts," J. of the Acoustical Society of America, Vol. 41, No. 5, May 1967.
C. M. Harris and C. E. Crede, "Shock and Vibration Handbook." Chapter VI (author F. E. Reed). New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co., Inc., 1961.
